measured_by: single-item 100-point Likert question: “What is the likelihood you would join this programme?”
justification: The Methods section states: “The primary outcome was a single-item question on willingness to join the described programme: ‘What is the likelihood you would join this programme?’ rated on a 100-point Likert scale.”

measured_by: percentage allocation across five listed techniques
justification: Under Manipulation checks: “we asked participants to indicate the share of each technique in percentages… The sum of all five techniques could not be more than 100.”

measured_by: single-item 100-point Likert question on how much the programme would reduce stress
justification: Sample features section notes: “We also asked participants to indicate to what extent they thought the advertised programme would reduce stress (100-point scale, definitely would not reduce stress…definitely would reduce stress).”
Previous experiences section says: “we asked all respondents… whether mindfulness was a common practice in their community (100-point scale, definitely not…definitely yes).”

measured_by: self-report yes/no item plus checklist of programme types
justification: Previous experiences section: “we asked respondents to report whether they had taken previously part in workplace-based self-improvement, health, or wellbeing programmes. Those responding ‘yes’ were asked to indicate in which types of programmes they had participated.”
construct: Prior participation in workplace self-improvement programmes

justification: The article states: “Where participants reported they had taken mindfulness or other contemplative practice programmes, we asked the length of lifetime experience with meditation in hours.”
